standards.benchmark: Use latitude and longitude coordinates to understand the relationship between people and places on the Earth.
standards.item_specs: Students use coordinate systems to locate places and describe spatial relationships.
essential_questions: How do we describe the location of places on Earth?
Why is the grid system important for navigation?
learning_targets: I can use latitude and longitude to find locations.
I can explain the purpose of the coordinate system.
I can interpret maps using grid coordinates.
standards.sample_assessment: The line of latitude at 0Â° is called the: A) Prime Meridian B) Equator C) Tropic of Cancer D) International Date Line

standards.benchmark: Utilize tools geographers use to study the world.
standards.item_specs: Students identify and use various geographic tools including maps, globes, and GIS.
essential_questions: What tools do geographers use to study Earth?
How has technology changed geographic study?
learning_targets: I can identify different types of maps and their purposes.
I can use map scales and legends.
I can explain how GIS technology helps geographers.
standards.sample_assessment: A thematic map would BEST be used to show: A) Physical features B) Political boundaries C) Population density patterns D) Street directions

standards.benchmark: Explain how major physical characteristics, natural resources, climate, and absolute and relative locations have influenced settlement, interactions, and the economies of ancient civilizations.
standards.item_specs: Students analyze relationships between physical geography and human development.
essential_questions: How does geography influence where people live?
What role do natural resources play in economic development?
learning_targets: I can explain how landforms affect human settlement.
I can analyze how climate influences human activity.
I can describe the relationship between resources and economy.
standards.sample_assessment: Ancient civilizations developed near rivers primarily because rivers provided: A) Defense from enemies B) Water for farming and transportation C) Gold deposits D) Building stone

standards.benchmark: Explain how the geographical factors influenced the economic development, political relationships, and policies of ancient civilizations.
standards.item_specs: Students analyze how geography shaped economic and political development.
essential_questions: How did geography determine trade routes?
Why did some civilizations become powerful while others did not?
learning_targets: I can explain how geography influenced trade.
I can analyze how geographic barriers affected political relationships.
I can describe how resources led to conflict or cooperation.
standards.sample_assessment: The Silk Road developed because: A) China was isolated from other civilizations B) There was demand for goods between East and West C) All civilizations spoke the same language D) The journey was short and easy

standards.benchmark: Explain how the physical landscape has affected the development of agriculture and industry in the ancient world.
standards.item_specs: Students explain connections between physical features and economic activities.
essential_questions: How did landscape determine what crops could be grown?
Why did industries develop in certain locations?
learning_targets: I can explain how terrain affects agriculture.
I can describe how access to resources influences industry.
I can analyze the relationship between geography and technology.
standards.sample_assessment: The Nile River's annual flooding was important to Egyptian agriculture because it: A) Destroyed crops B) Deposited fertile soil C) Prevented farming D) Created deserts

standards.benchmark: Explain how family, ethnic, national, and professional identity have led to the development and maintenance of cultural traditions and norms.
standards.item_specs: Students explain how identity shapes cultural practices.
essential_questions: Why do cultural traditions persist over time?
learning_targets: I can explain how family shapes cultural identity.
I can describe how ethnic traditions are maintained.
I can analyze how geography influences cultural development.
standards.sample_assessment: Cultural traditions are MOST often passed down through: A) Written laws B) Family and community C) Government mandates D) Economic systems

standards.benchmark: Identify the methods used to compensate for the scarcity of resources in the ancient world.
standards.item_specs: Students identify how ancient peoples addressed resource limitations.
essential_questions: How did ancient peoples deal with scarce resources?
learning_targets: I can identify resources that were scarce in ancient times.
I can explain how trade addressed scarcity.
I can describe technological innovations that compensated for scarcity.
standards.sample_assessment: Ancient Mesopotamians compensated for lack of building stone by: A) Not building permanent structures B) Using mud bricks C) Importing stone from far away D) Building only in caves

standards.benchmark: Describe the Six Essential Elements of Geography.
standards.item_specs: Students identify and describe the six essential elements of geography.
essential_questions: What are the essential elements of geographic study?
How do geographers organize their knowledge?
learning_targets: I can list the Six Essential Elements of Geography.
I can explain what each element studies.
I can give examples of each element.
standards.sample_assessment: Which Essential Element of Geography deals with how humans modify and adapt to their environment? A) Location B) Place C) Human-Environment Interaction D) Movement
